intro: Carum graecum subsp. graecum, commonly known as Greek cumin, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves and small white to greenish flowers. Its seeds, which are often used as a spice, are harvested when mature and dried. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for both culinary and ornamental purposes.
